author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Fisherman Last Sighted Two Weeks Ago Rescued at Sea
description: A fishing vessel with two aboard left Washington State on Oct. 12 and was reported missing on Sunday. On Thursday, one of the men was rescued, officials said.
content: Canadian fishermen help hoist a man wearing a green hat and a blue plaid shirt onto a Canadian Coast Guard rescue boat that has pulled alongside them. As the man steadies himself, he turns around and says, “Thanks a lot guys,” then waves as the Coast Guard boat pulls away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nguyen
title: ‘The Berry Pickers’ Is a Harrowing Tale of Indigenous Family Separation
description: In Amanda Peters’s debut novel, a 4-year-old Mi’kmaw girl disappears one summer, prompting a lifelong saga of mystery and tragedy.
content: It is 1962 and a Mi’kmaw family crosses from Nova Scotia into Maine to harvest berries as migrant workers. Once they arrive, everything falls into a summer rhythm, but one afternoon, the family’s youngest, 4-year-old Ruthie, disappears. Her brother Joe is the last to see her, which will haunt him for the rest of his life. As he grows up, more tragedies befall him: After witnessing the murder of his brother, he emotionally spirals, feeling that he is bad luck to his family, which leads him first to the bottle, then to an accident that disables him and to an act of violence that causes him to leave the life he knows behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Oct. 21-27
description: This week’s toughest challenge may have been a little bombastic.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Lisa Lerer and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Pence Bows Out of 2024 Presidential Race That Trump Is Dominating
description: The former vice president said he would end his bid in a surprise announcement at a gathering of Jewish Republican donors. “It’s become clear to me that this is not my time,” he said.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence, who spent four years dutifully serving President Donald J. Trump but refused to carry out Mr. Trump’s demand that he block the 2020 election results, ended his presidential bid on Saturday, with a final appeal for his party to return to conservative principles and resist the “siren song of populism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: ‘You Think of Dying at Any Time’
description: Gaza residents say Israeli airstrikes come mostly without warning and hit indiscriminately, leading to the feeling that death is imminent and inevitable.
content: Nayrouz Qarmout, a Palestinian author who lives in the Gaza Strip, recalled that during past wars with Israel, Gazans would feel extreme pangs of fear when they heard explosions, but afterward hope would return. Hope of cease-fires, and of life going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: And the Call Was Coming From the Basement
description: Zombie raccoons, David Sedaris and haunted houses.
content: For the lead-up to Halloween, scary stories that are all true. Zombie raccoons, real haunted houses and things that go “EEEEK!!!” in the night. Plus, a story by David Sedaris, in which he walks among the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: On Race, Mike Johnson Says His Views Were Shaped by Raising a Black Child
description: The new House speaker has kept his oldest son out of the public eye — except when the Republican talks about race.
content: When Mike Johnson, the new House speaker, talks about race in America, he often draws a striking personal connection, telling the story of how he and his wife, Kelly, “took custody” of a Black teenager 24 years ago and raised him as a son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Ruth Graham and Steve Eder
title: For Mike Johnson, Religion Is at the Forefront of Politics and Policy
description: The new House speaker has put his faith at the center of his political career, and aligned himself with a newer cohort of conservative Christianity that some describe as Christian nationalism.
content: In the moments before he was to face a vote on becoming speaker of the House this week, Representative Mike Johnson posted a photograph on social media of the inscription carved into marble atop the chamber’s rostrum: “In God We Trust.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: If Airbnbs Are Illegal, How Does My Neighbor Still Get Away With It?
description: Most co-ops require shareholders to comply with local laws and regulations, not just their own rules.
content: Q: I live in a midsize co-op building in the West Village. A rent-stabilized tenant on the first floor had listed a room in her apartment on Airbnb for years, until such rentals were prohibited. We also registered our building on the city’s prohibited buildings list. Her Airbnb listing was removed, but she continues to rent out a room (or the whole apartment, we’re not sure) on Facebook Marketplace. We’ve shared this information with the apartment’s sponsor and several others in our building. The sponsor hasn’t told the tenant to stop this illegal practice. What rights does the co-op have here? Can we evict the tenant, or take action against the sponsor?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joanna Merlin, Known for Her Work Both Onstage and Off, Dies at 92
description: Soon after appearing in the original Broadway production of “Fiddler on the Roof,” she began a new career as a prominent casting director.
content: Joanna Merlin, who, after originating the role of Tzeitel, the eldest daughter, in the hit Broadway musical “Fiddler on the Roof,” became a renowned casting director, notably for Stephen Sondheim musicals including “Into the Woods” and “Follies,” died on Oct. 15 at her younger daughter’s home in Los Angeles. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Haley Offers Scathing Critique of Trump at Jewish Republican Event in Las Vegas
description: At the annual Republican Jewish Coalition gathering, G.O.P. leaders are seizing political opportunities in the divisions that the conflict has opened up at home.
content: A series of speeches by Republican presidential candidates on Saturday to a large gathering of Jewish donors and activists demonstrated how the escalating conflict in the Middle East has elevated foreign policy into a dominant campaign issue and exposed fresh divides within the primary contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: Practical Magic: The Lucrative Business of Being a Witch on Etsy and TikTok
description: Modern witches no longer lurk in dark alleys or operate out of the back rooms of stores, you can instead buy their services online for a pretty penny or two.
content: When Maira Khan’s boyfriend left her last year, she was desperate to win him back. “I knew he was seeing someone else, but I didn’t know how serious it was,” said Ms. Khan, an influencer in Toronto. “I kind of just wanted her gone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Green Beans With Plenty of Texture and Spice
description: The almond butter in Priya Krishna’s clever new sabzi makes for an almost tempura-like coating.
content: You can never have too many green bean or broccoli recipes. These two Kelly green vegetables are present at every grocery store, have a subtle sweetness and lend themselves well to all manner of cooking: roasting, steaming, blanching, or even raw. Priya Krishna’s new green bean and potato sabzi is an excellent addition to your green bean repertoire. In a clever twist, Priya uses almond butter to give the veggies an almost tempura-like coating, and a dusting of chaat masala gives the finished dish a tart, salty sparkle. You could tuck this recipe into your broccoli folder as well: The florets may need an extra minute or two of cook time, but they make an excellent sub for the green beans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Books for a Mental Vacation
description: Madeleine L’Engle’s domestic memoir; Julie Orringer’s humane short stories
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

title: Improving Treatments for Children With Cancer
description: Readers, including Christie Brinkley, discuss a column by Pamela Paul about the lifelong health issues these children face.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 28, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about Georgia’s voting maps misstated the year that Georgia elected its two Democratic senators. It was 2021, not 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: When Your Age, and Everyone Else’s, Is Showing
description: Colleagues of different generations can bridge age gaps. But first, they must ask some questions.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Raúl Vilchis
title: Migrants Search for Beds as New York Quietly Stops Offering Them to All
description: “They want you to get tired so you give up, and they are achieving it,” said one migrant who has been searching for a place to stay in New York City for several days.
content: On Thursday, Vinicius Funes, a 26-year-old migrant from Honduras, went in search of a bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Maggie Haberman
title: How Cohen’s Testimony Sets the Stage for Trump’s Hush Money Trial
description: Michael D. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s former fixer, was not an essential witness in Mr. Trump’s civil fraud trial this week. He will be when he takes the stand in a Manhattan criminal case.
content: As Michael D. Cohen prepared to take the stand at the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump this week, two women who shared an intense interest in his testimony slipped into the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Haberman
title: Vocal on Israel, DeSantis Is Challenged on His Silence on Neo-Nazis in Florida
description: One of the governor’s closest Jewish allies in the state publicly switched his support to Donald J. Trump, citing past incidents.
content: As Israel’s war against Hamas has become an animating force in the Republican presidential primary, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has cast himself as a staunch defender of the Jewish state, sending taxpayer-funded charter flights to rescue Americans stranded in Israel, calling for harsh measures against the civilians of Gaza and ordering pro-Palestinian groups on public university campuses in his state to disband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Lured by Federal Dollars, Canadian Cities Rethink Zoning
description: Major Canadian cities are opening up development zoning to include fourplexes in exchange for federal funds to build housing.
content: Fourplexes, multiunit dwellings that are relatively rare in Canada — a country where detached homes dominate residential streets — appear set to become more prominent in major cities. The lure of federal cash to build housing is causing many municipalities to bend staunch zoning rules that once prohibited fourplexes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Joey Evans Is Back. This Time He’s a Struggling Artist.
description: A new “Pal Joey” at City Center has reimagined the never-quite-satisfying script to make Joey (Ephraim Sykes) a forward-thinking Black jazz singer.
content: Joey Evans is a charming cad, a heel, an unapologetic womanizer, a gigolo. He’s a second-rate nightclub entertainer who breaks the heart of an ingénue and seduces a rich older woman, trading sex for money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: TikTok’s Finest Lobsterman
description: A new crop of popular social media personalities includes a trucker, a shepherd and a commercial fisherman. What they earn from sponsorships is just a nice bonus.
content: It was another busy day for the crew of the Rest-Ashoar, a lobster fishing boat that works the waters off the rocky coast of Winter Harbor, Maine. The captain, Jacob Knowles, had gotten up at 3 a.m. on a brisk October morning and took his vessel 10 miles into the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK to Hire a Surrogate to Bear Twins?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the financial realities of family planning.
content: My husband and I want to have children, and as a gay couple, we think that surrogacy is our most realistic option. Surrogacy, however, is expensive. It could easily cost between $150,000 and $200,000 per pregnancy. We could afford two rounds, but this would deplete nearly all our savings. We are well-off, but don’t come from especially affluent backgrounds, and it took a long time to accumulate these savings. These savings, in part, are for our future retirement too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Ghostly Presence
description: In a time when everything’s gone virtual, Halloween costumes represent an old-fashioned commitment to the physical world.
content: Tombstones are planted in the flower beds. A witch appears to have flown into a tree and is suspended there, broom sticking out from the trunk. An undead crone, motion sensitive, accosts passers-by from the hedge. On my otherwise very quiet, very nothing-to-see-here Brooklyn block, there’s a lot to see this time of year. I arrive home to tourists taking pictures with the skeletons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Ernesto Londoño
title: In Michigan, Muslim and Arab American Voters Reconsider Support for Biden
description: Many in the swing state say they feel betrayed by the president’s support for Israel.
content: Sam Baydoun, a Wayne County commissioner in Dearborn, Mich., has been glued to Al Jazeera for weeks to absorb news from the war in Israel and Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benzion Sanders
title: I Fought for the I.D.F. in Gaza. It Made Me Fight for Peace.
description: An Israeli veteran reflects on his experience the last time Israeli troops entered Gaza in force.
content: When my Israeli infantry unit arrived at the first village in Gaza, in July 2014, we cleared houses by sending grenades through windows, blowing doors open and firing bullets into rooms to avoid ambush and booby traps. We were told Palestinian civilians had fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Israel Says Al Shifa Hospital Conceals Hamas Underground Command Centers
description: The group denies the accusation, saying Israel has offered “fabricated” evidence.
content: To people in Gaza, Al Shifa is the biggest and most advanced hospital around — a lifeline, in normal times, and now a place of refuge from relentless Israeli airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: The ‘Silver Lining to the Pandemic’ for Working Mothers
description: The share of women working has reached a record high, with the biggest increases among mothers of children under 5.
content: The share of American women working for pay is at a record high. According to a recent analysis, the surge has been led by an unexpected group: mothers of children under 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: CUNY Halts Investigation of Alzheimer’s Researcher
description: Citing questions about the integrity of the process, the university said that “no final action” had been taken.
content: The City University of New York is pausing its investigation into a faculty member, an Alzheimer’s researcher accused of misconduct, the university said in a statement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Team Trump Revives Attack Ads Against DeSantis in Iowa
description: A super PAC supporting Trump is shifting its strategy again, with less than three months before the state’s first-in-the-nation caucuses.
content: The super PAC supporting Donald J. Trump will begin airing an attack against Ron DeSantis in Iowa, a shift in strategy after months of focusing their messaging on their likely general election opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Minor Earthquake Under San Francisco’s Airport Rattles Nerves
description: The 3.7-magnitude quake was felt in the San Francisco Bay Area during the Friday evening rush. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
content: A 3.7-magnitude earthquake hit San Francisco on Friday evening, with an epicenter under the city’s international airport, the United States Geological Survey said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Fabric-ations
description: Alina Abidi whips up a cozy Sunday puzzle debut.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
title: A.I. Muddies Israel-Hamas War in Unexpected Way
description: Fakes related to the conflict have been limited and largely unconvincing, but their presence has people doubting real evidence.
content: It was a gruesome image that shot rapidly around the internet: a charred body, described as a deceased child, that was apparently photographed in the opening days of the conflict between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Early Voting Begins in New York: Here’s What to Know
description: Although no citywide offices are being contested this year, the New York City Council is up for election, and voters statewide will consider two ballot questions.
content: Election Day is still several days away, but voters in New York can get a head start on Saturday, when early voting begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Montano and Damon Winter
title: America’s Disaster Recovery System Is a Disaster
description: The help Americans receive after disasters isn’t just inadequate, it’s complicated to navigate and painfully slow to arrive.
content: This summer, 12 people let me into their lives to tell me about their experiences in the aftermath of disasters, including hurricanes, floods, freezes, wildfires and derechos. All said, they did not receive the aid they expected, and the effects have been devastating. “It’s been a very humbling experience, to say the least, to go from ‘We’re fine, we just got a new house, we have a huge savings, biggest we’ve ever had’ to ‘You have nothing and you lost everything and you have to go to food pantries for food,’” said Aleasha LeClere, whose life was turned upside down by a 2020 derecho in Iowa. According to research on disasters and advocacy groups, these survivors’ experiences are very much the norm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Tania Ganguli
title: With Fans Ever More Fickle, Sports Leagues Warm to Rule Changes
description: Baseball’s pitch clock is just one example of how professional sports are competing for public attention in an ever-evolving entertainment world.
content: Texas Rangers fans are hoping the slugger Adolis Garcia can blast the franchise to its first World Series title. Arizona supporters know the Diamondbacks need to continue being greedy on the basepaths if they’re to capture a second championship. Everyone else watching has already won, thanks to a pitch clock, bigger bases and a made-over American pastime that is faster and more balletic and gets them to bed earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel-Hamas War Enters ‘Second Stage,’ Netanyahu Says
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not describe the ground incursion as an invasion, but it was accompanied by an enormous aerial and artillery bombardment.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a televised news conference on Saturday that Israel’s forces had entered the Gaza Strip, calling it his country’s “second war of independence” and warning Israelis to expect a “long and difficult” campaign to eradicate Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. M. Akers
title: Is It Time to Pull Up Stakes and Head for Mars?
description: Probably not, Kelly and Zach Weinersmith argue in “A City on Mars.”
content: Face it, folks. Earth is finished. It’s overheated, overcrowded, overregulated. It’s the ultimate fixer-upper, a dump we inherited from our parents that we’d be cruel to pass on to our children. It’s time to pull up stakes. It’s time for Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub, Emily Schmall, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
title: Chapter 2: Chasing Dreams at a Steep Cost
description: She escaped an abusive betrothal, but her family’s reputation was suffering for it.
content: As Nasreen Parveen ran, her mind focused on nothing but putting one foot in front of the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Tiffany May and Claire Fu
title: As China Looks to Broker Gaza Peace, Antisemitism Surges Online
description: China’s state-run media has blamed the United States for deepening the crisis, while perpetuating tropes of Jewish control of American politics.
content: As the Israel-Hamas conflict intensifies, raising the prospect of a wider war, China has stepped up efforts to pitch itself as a neutral broker for Mideast peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Victory Hamas Has Already Won
description: When barbarity has a revolutionary logic.
content: In 2014, a new state was formed in the heart of the Middle East. It had a capital, a government, an army and almost 12 million subjects — a larger population than Jordan or Israel. It also had a commitment to butchery, savagery and fanatical violence that quickly earned it the enmity of the entire civilized world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Iranian Teenager Dies Weeks After Mysterious Collapse
description: The death of Armita Geravand comes after word of her injuries fueled outrage because she was so young and because of previous cases in which women have been brutalized for protesting dress codes.
content: Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old Iranian high school student, has died weeks after she collapsed and fell into a coma following what many believe was an encounter over not covering her hair in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Helene Cooper and Justin Scheck
title: Gaza’s Tunnels Loom Large for Israel’s Ground Forces
description: Hamas is believed to hide weapons, fighters and even command centers in miles of subterranean pathways and chambers.
content: Just after midnight on Tuesday, the Israel Defense Forces announced that they had struck a tunnel that allowed Hamas to “infiltrate Israel through the sea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sakeina Syed
title: Weddings at the Edge of the World
description: How far would you go for your wedding? These adventurous couples trekked to Mount Everest base camp, skied down the Rockies and swam in the Cozumel Channel to say “I do.”
content: To reach their wedding venue, Austin O’Reilly and Iulia O’Reilly crossed a swaying suspension bridge, trying not to glance down at the glacial river below. With each step, the bridge shook under the weight of people and yaks. Mr. O’Reilly, 25, had seen similar bridges in the 2015 movie “Everest.” Now, he was on that titular mountain with his fiancée: walking a precarious bridge, crossing jagged moraines and traversing rocky terrain on a nine-day trek to the Everest base camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: A Tech Overlord’s Horrifying, Silly Vision for Who Should Rule the World
description: It’s no mystery why Marc Andreessen thinks people like him should be in charge. But how did he get so many of the rest of us to sign on?
content: It takes a certain kind of person to write grandiose manifestoes for public consumption, unafflicted by self-doubt or denuded of self-interest. The latest example is Marc Andreessen, a co-founder of the top-tier venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and best known, to those of us who came of age before TikTok, as a co-founder of the pioneering internet browser Netscape. In “The Techno-Optimist Manifesto,” a recent 5,000-plus-word post on the Andreessen Horowitz website, Mr. Andreessen outlines a vision of technologists as the authors of a future in which the “techno-capital machine” produces everything that is good in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The House G.O.P Has Its Leader. But Can He Be a Rainmaker?
description: The former speaker, Kevin McCarthy, was a prolific fund-raiser for his House colleagues. The new speaker, Mike Johnson, doesn’t yet have the same juice.
content: The decision to oust Kevin McCarthy as speaker and replace him with a little-known congressman, Mike Johnson of Louisiana, has left a glaring financial gap for House Republicans headed into 2024 when the party has to defend its narrow and fragile majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Main Problem With Pedestrian Deaths Isn’t the Pedestrians
description: When drivers rule the road, irresponsibility becomes fatal.
content: I want to talk about two things that have happened since last weekend’s newsletter on pedestrian deaths. One of them was covered in this newspaper, and the other was a personal experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: The Real End of David Chang’s Momofuku Ko Happened Years Ago
description: The revolutionary tasting-menu restaurant eventually came to resemble the fine-dining titans it tried to dethrone.
content: David Chang is “pausing operations” at Momofuku Ko next week, according to a post on his company’s Instagram account. It goes on: “we won’t call this a goodbye, but ko will no longer operate in the way it has.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Hawaii Settles Sex Discrimination Case With High School Female Athletes
description: The landmark class-action case was one of the farthest-reaching challenges to high school sports under federal Title IX protections.
content: Hawaii education officials on Friday agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit filed by female athletes at the state’s biggest public high school alleging widespread and systemic sex discrimination, as well as retaliation against the girls who raised those concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Gunman in Maine Mass Shooting Had Paranoid Beliefs, Officials Say
description: The man was found dead on Friday night, ending a two-day manhunt. The police said he had legally purchased several guns, including in recent days.
content: The man who killed 18 people and wounded 13 more in Lewiston, Maine, the deadliest mass shooting in America this year, had paranoid beliefs that people were talking about him, and he may have been hearing voices, the authorities said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Jenna Russell and Michael Levenson
title: Suspect in Maine Shooting Is Found Dead, Ending Sprawling Manhunt
description: The body of the man suspected of killing 18 and injuring 13 others in Lewiston was found with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound late Friday.
content: The man suspected of killing 18 people and injuring 13 others at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday night was found dead of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound on Friday, officials said, ending a sweeping manhunt that had forced thousands of residents throughout the region to remain in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Without Getting Beat
description: Ryan McCarty’s puzzle looks impossible, but we’ll claw through.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a puzzle comes along that makes my solving skills feel paltry, a teaspoon of water on a swirling inferno of misdirects and unfamiliar pop culture. On a Saturday, that puzzle is often by Ryan McCarty, who now has 22 such constructions under his belt. They are always entertaining, confounding and full of debuts and eccentric usages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Meg Ryan Wrestles With the Rom-Com
description: She always had concerns about the happily-ever-after ideals of the genre. Now as a director she’s pushing its boundaries to examine issues of aging and regret.
content: Meg Ryan was hurting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Deal With Stellantis, Following Ford
description: The United Automobile Workers union announced the deal with Stellantis, the parent of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram. It also expanded its strike against G.M.
content: The United Automobile Workers union announced on Saturday that it had reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract with Stellantis, the parent company of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: ‘Annika’ Star Nicola Walker on the Book She’d Save From a Burning Home
description: When it comes to the actress’s favorite things, give her the American version of “Alone” and a true-crime podcast from Australia.
content: No one broods quite like Nicola Walker, whose eyes have transfixed viewers in television shows like “Unforgotten,” “Last Tango in Halifax” and “The Split.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: A Dispatch From the Muslim Girl Scouts of Astoria
description: A young activist in Queens supports Palestinian aspirations.
content: In her short 17 years on earth, Amira Ismail had never been called a baby killer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: At Least 32 Killed in Vehicle Pileup in Egypt
description: Several cars caught fire after a passenger bus and several vehicles collided on a main road north of Cairo, injuring more than 60 other people, state media reported.
content: CAIRO — At least 32 people were killed and 63 others injured on Saturday morning in Egypt after a passenger bus and several vehicles collided about 82 miles north of the capital, Cairo, the health ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Israeli Approach to Ground War in Gaza Aligns with U.S. Advice, Officials Say
description: The initial decision to undertake limited ground incursions rather than a full-scale invasion appears to follow guidance from top U.S. military officials.
content: Israel’s apparent decision to hold off on a full-scale invasion of the Gaza Strip and instead conduct more limited ground incursions, at least initially, aligns with suggestions that the U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, made to his Israeli counterparts in recent days, American officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cole Stangler
title: There Is Another Paris
description: With a little bit of time and patience, you can still find it.
content: Tourists visiting the Sacré-Coeur Basilica, the magnificent snow-white cathedral towering over northern Paris, tend to descend the Butte Montmartre the way they came up. After visiting the church, they might make a stop at the Place du Tertre, the historic square of Montmartre encircled by restaurants promising authentic French cuisine at unauthentically French prices. They might admire the dozens of street artists churning out quick sketches of passers-by and peddling hastily made watercolors. They might even jostle to the edge of the square to sneak a final glance at the city from one of its highest points. But once they’ve had enough, they’ll most likely make their way down the south side of the hill, following the path of the funicular toward the recognizable sights of central Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: ‘A Bright Light in a Dark Time’: A New School for Uvalde
description: More than a year after a mass shooting at Robb Elementary School, the community broke ground on a new campus.
content: In the year since a teenage gunman strode into Robb Elementary School in Uvalde and killed 19 fourth graders and two teachers, the building has stood empty, its windows boarded over, its students dispersed to other campuses with little chance to maintain the bonds they once shared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Elda Cantú
title: Pleas for Aid and a Scramble for Supplies in Acapulco After Hurricane Otis
description: Days after the storm, the death toll rose to 39 and residents were navigating broken glass, searching for water and food, and trying to find loved ones. Many said the government was not doing enough.
content: The tourists were bused out of Acapulco to find relief as far away as Mexico’s capital. But thousands of residents were left behind to deal with the chaos and destruction of Hurricane Otis, which had turned their paradise into a wasteland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy, Julian Roberts-Grmela, Sean Piccoli and Erin Nolan
title: ‘Let Gaza Live’: Calls for Cease-Fire Fill Grand Central Terminal
description: A large demonstration, organized by Jewish Voice for Peace, came as Israel ramped up its military operations in Gaza.
content: Hundreds of protesters calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war streamed into Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan on Friday, in one of the largest protests New York City has seen since the start of the conflict three weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Two Plead Guilty in Alabama Riverfront Brawl
description: A man and a woman pleaded guilty on Friday to charges related to an attack on a Black boat captain that garnered widespread attention and backlash on social media.
content: More than two months after a group of white boaters attacked a Black riverboat captain in Montgomery, Ala., two of five people charged in connection with the racially charged melee pleaded guilty on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Violence Grinds On in Sudan, Putting a Generation of Students at Risk
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 28, 2023.
content: “I am starting from zero.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden’s Israel Ties Rooted in Long Career: ‘From His Gut to His Heart to His Head’
description: The president’s “unwavering support” for Israel stems from childhood dinner table conversations and half a century of trips to the Jewish state. But it puts him at odds with some in his own party.
content: One morning during a spasm of violence two decades ago, with suicide bombings shattering Israel every other day, the King David Hotel in Jerusalem seemed eerily empty. Foreigners were staying away. Nobody was in the dining room. Except for two people having breakfast: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his aide, Antony J. Blinken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Kremlin’s Onetime Pick to Be Ukraine’s Puppet Leader Is Shot in Crimea
description: Oleg Tsaryov, a pro-Russian businessman and former lawmaker, was said to have been wounded in the attack. Moscow had planned to set him up as head of government in Kyiv if its invasion had succeeded.
content: A Ukrainian former lawmaker whom the Kremlin had handpicked to lead a puppet administration in Kyiv, Ukraine, was shot and wounded in occupied Crimea in an apparent assassination attempt, Ukrainian and Russian officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Joe Nocera
title: Is Crypto Financing Terrorism?
description: A report that terror groups raised more than $130 million in crypto during recent years has set off a debate in Washington and finance circles.
content: The United States will go after cryptocurrency firms that fail to stop terrorist groups from moving money, the U.S. deputy Treasury secretary, Wally Adeyemo, warned on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Frangipane
title: How ‘Madame Morbid,’ a Ghost Tour Guide, Spends Her Sundays
description: Allison Chase leads tours of Brooklyn’s gruesome history, hidden cemeteries and paranormal sightings in a replica Victorian trolley.
content: Allison Chase was at a crossroads and venting to her father about the direction of her life at 26 years old. Having dabbled in doing special effects makeup, writing restaurant reviews and obtaining a sommelier certificate, she quipped half in jest, “What if I want to start a ghost tour?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Deems Bigger Church Role for Women ‘Urgent,’ but Postpones Major Issues
description: Progressives who once hoped that the synod would create momentum for things like reaching out to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics said the meeting had failed to move the institution.
content: A monthlong meeting convened by Pope Francis to determine the future of the Roman Catholic Church ended Saturday night with a document that said it was “urgent” that women have a larger role but postponed discussion of major issues such as ordaining women as deacons and failed to address outreach to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘We Are Overpaying the Price for a Sin We Didn’t Commit’
description: Israel has every right to defend itself and fight terrorists. But is this really the best way?
content: The most consequential decision Israel will face in the coming days is how hard to continue hitting Gaza. Should it undertake a monthslong ground invasion? Continue with large-scale aerial bombardment? Allow fuel into Gaza to keep hospitals running?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai
title: Fitting Race in a Box
description: We explain what the next census could look like.
content: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Writing ‘Maid’ Pulled Stephanie Land Out of Poverty. She’s Fine Now, Right?
description: Despite writing a best seller that became a hit Netflix series, Ms. Land says she still worries about her job security.
content: What do you do with the money you earn from a story you wrote about not having much for too many years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Rosen
title: A Night of Reading, Cover to Uncover
description: The author of “On Fire Island” wasn’t sure what to expect when she was invited to appear at a “Books & Burlesque” event. Here’s her unblushing report.
content: Early in the summer, an unusual email popped up in my inbox. Sandwiched between a podcast request and an offer to speak at a South Florida chapter of Hadassah was an invitation to read an excerpt from my latest novel, “On Fire Island,” at a “Books & Burlesque” evening on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. The event, as the show’s producers Fortune Cookie and Rosie Tulips explained, would feature five writers reading, each paired with a burlesque or drag artist creating an act inspired by the author’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Desperate for Air Defense, Ukraine Pushes U.S. for ‘Franken’ Weapons
description: To meet the demand, the U.S. is producing so-called FrankenSAM systems that marry advanced Western weaponry with Soviet-era items still in Ukrainian stockpiles.
content: With winter approaching, Ukrainian officials are desperate for more air defenses to protect their power grids from Russian strikes that could plunge the country into freezing darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: ‘Lewiston Strong’: After Mass Shooting, Residents Emerge With Grit
description: After two long days of being locked down amid the manhunt for a gunman who killed 18 people, the small city in Maine started to come back to life, forever changed.
content: On a sparkling October morning, with peak fall foliage blazing red and yellow, the residents of Lewiston emerged from two long days of lockdown on Saturday into a city forever changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: A Man Orphaned by Hamas Calls on Israel: Stop the ‘Cycle of Blood’
description: Nicholas Kristof reports from Tel Aviv.
content: Maoz Inon last spoke with his 78-year-old father and 75-year-old mother on Oct. 7, shortly before they were murdered by Hamas. In this audio essay, he tells Nicholas Kristof why he wants a cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Richard Moll, Towering Bailiff on ‘Night Court,’ Dies at 80
description: His career spanned more than four decades, but he was best known for playing the imposing but lovable Bull Shannon on the long-running NBC sitcom.
content: Richard Moll, the 6-foot-8 actor who delighted television audiences with a childlike charm in his role as the hulking bailiff on the NBC sitcom “Night Court,” died on Thursday at his home in Big Bear Lake, Calif. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: After Shooting, Maine Senators in the Spotlight on Guns
description: The shooting in Lewiston that left 18 dead prompted the town’s conservative Democratic representative to embrace an assault weapons ban, but Senators Susan Collins and Angus King are still resisting.
content: The mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, coupled with a conservative Democratic congressman’s reversal on an assault weapons ban, has turned the spotlight on the state’s two senators, Susan Collins, a moderate Republican, and Angus King, a Democrat-leaning independent, both of whom are skeptical about banning military-style rifles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Hannah Reyes Morales
title: The World Is Becoming More African
description: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African. Early tremors of this seismic change are already registering around the world.
content: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African. Early tremors of this seismic change are already registering around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Residents Awaiting Help Resort to Looting in Acapulco
description: Military planes carrying food and water have begun to arrive in Acapulco, Mexico, but residents say the aid is not enough after Hurricane Otis caused widespread destruction.
content: Military planes carrying food and water have begun to arrive in Acapulco, Mexico, but residents say the aid is not enough after Hurricane Otis caused widespread destruction.
source.name: The New York Times
